title: 110_s2476
content: The "Improved Vaccine Supply Act" is cited as the short title. It amends the Public Health Service Act to include a new section on the adequate supply of vaccines. The Secretary, through the CDC Director, must develop a plan for purchasing and storing vaccines for a 6-month supply for children and adults. This supply must include all vaccines recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. The Secretary is required to supply vaccines recommended for children and adults by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, as well as other designated vaccines for public health preparedness efforts. The authority for supplying vaccines for children is under the Social Security Act, and for adults, it is designated by the Secretary. The Secretary must submit a plan for supplying vaccines for public health preparedness efforts to specified Senate committees within 6 months of enactment. The Secretary must submit a plan for purchasing vaccines to Senate committees within 6 months of enactment, including considerations and prioritization. The plan must be fully implemented by September 30, 2008. The Secretary must implement a plan for purchasing vaccines by September 30, 2008. Manufacturers must provide at least 1 year notice of any vaccine discontinuance. Manufacturers of vaccines must give the Secretary at least 1 year notice of discontinuance. The notification period can be reduced with good cause. Proceeds from vaccine sales go towards purchasing additional vaccines. Proceeds from vaccine sales are used by the Secretary to purchase more vaccines. The Secretary must provide ongoing reports on the progress and any obstacles in implementing the plan developed under subsection (a). The Secretary must submit a report detailing progress and obstacles in implementing the plan, along with a recommendation on extending the vaccine supply beyond 6 months. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this section. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this section to cover fiscal years 2008 through 2012.
